attributes.title: Stock verification
attributes.description:
A physical stock count was done on 01/06/2025 to determine if inventory controls were working effectively and to determine if Physical stock items were matching with those in SAP.

The exercise showed the following:

Bread stock had a variance of +23 pieces

Polybags had -57 pieces 

White flour had-12.46Kgs ,Brown flour had -3.61 Kgs

White ingredient had -1.08 Kgs,

utto had +1.25 kgs and yeast had +0.93 sachets.

Below is a detailed summary of the audit findings:
attributes.recommendation: Branch management is recommended to ensure proper recording of movement of raw materials is done to eliminate the noted variations.
attributes.effect: The Minimal stock variations noted implies that stock controls are working effectively.

value: We will do a follow up to ensure proper recording of movement of raw materials is done to minimize the noted variations.
The raw materials and finished goods are in good controls. Shift wise stocks are being contacted to make sure variations are minimal.

In the previous audit report dated 13/04/2025,the following were noted

  • Bread stock had +23.75 pieces cumulatively

  • Poly bags had a variance of +1,539 pieces cumulatively

  • Utto 1.738 litres

  • Other raw materials had insignificant variations.
Current

As part of routine internal control measures, a physical stock count was conducted on 01 June 2025 to assess the accuracy and reliability of inventory records maintained in the SAP system. The primary objective of this exercise was to evaluate whether actual physical stock levels align with recorded quantities and to determine the effectiveness of existing inventory controls. The audit covered key inventory items including bread, polybags, various types of flour, ingredients, and packaging materials. Discrepancies between physical counts and system records were identified, highlighting potential gaps in stock management processes.

The results of the stock count revealed notable variances between the physical quantities and the SAP records across several inventory items. These inconsistencies suggest potential issues in stock recording, handling, or monitoring processes. While some items showed overages, others showed shortages, indicating the need for improved inventory reconciliation practices and stronger internal controls. It is recommended that management investigates the root causes of these variances, reinforces stock handling procedures, and enhances staff training to ensure greater accuracy and accountability in future stock management
Operations/Production Department
To determine if inventory controls were working effectively and to determine if Physical stock items were matching with those in SAP.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart analysis
attributes.description:
Analysis of both Mixing chart and mixing chart summary was done for a period of 48 days from 15th April  2025-01st May 2025,Average yield was at 189.35 which was slighly below the branch Yield of 191,Average daily production target was at 31.10 of 54 which represent 57.60% branch capacity utilization,141 remixes were noted and utto consumption to bags was 1:1.

Below is the summar of the audit findings:
attributes.recommendation: Sales team to work on onboarding more customers to ensure branch capacity is fully utilized,
attributes.effect:
Target production in bags was not achieved meaning the branch’s capacity was

under utilized

value: Branch sales for Grande is high hence the Branch produces more grande whose yield is 188 hence this affects the overall yield.
Currently branch is producing a lot of 400gm long  compared to 400 gm ct due to high demand of grande thus affecting overal branch yield.

In the prior audit report dated 13/04/2025,the following were noted

Average yield per bag was189.27per bag.

Utto consumption was at 100%.

Average production was 29.39 bags per day representing 54.42% of target which is 54 bags per day (Branch Capacity).
Current

An analysis was conducted on the Mixing Chart and Mixing Chart Summary over a 48-day period from 15 April 2025 to 01 June 2025 to assess production efficiency, yield consistency, and resource utilization. The review aimed to evaluate operational performance against branch standards and identify areas for improvement in mixing processes. Key metrics such as average yield, daily production targets, remix frequency, and ingredient-to-output ratios were examined to determine overall process effectiveness.

The analysis revealed that the average yield during the review period stood at 189.35, slightly below the branch benchmark of 191, indicating marginal inefficiencies in the mixing process. Production output achieved only 57.60% of the branch’s full capacity, with an average daily target of 31.10 out of 54. Additionally, remixes of  (141) were recorded, suggesting potential issues  process consistency. Notably, utto consumption maintained a consistent 1:1 ratio with bag output, which indicates stable usage of this ingredient. These findings highlight opportunities for enhancing yield performance, reducing remix rates, and optimizing production capacity utilization.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if the raw materials’ consumption were as per the set BOM and if the set yield and quality standards were achieved for production.

attributes.title: Bread weights
attributes.description:
Weight check was also done on the packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market on 02/06/2025 to determine if they were of correct weight. Significant underweights were noted in 800g CTW with 73.5%

Below is the summary of audit findings:
attributes.recommendation:
Follow the established quality and weight standards for bread to reduce the occurrences of both underweight and overweight loaves.

A steady and continuous observation of the production flow is necessary to avoid instances of overcooled bread.
attributes.effect:
The presence of both underweight and overweight bread highlighted shortcomings in the

enforcement of the established dough weight standards for certain varieties, as well as a

failure to monitor the production process effectively, leading to increased chances of bread

overcooling.

Underweights also expose the company to potential of penalties for non-compliance.

value: There was an order for Meru hence the slicers focused more on slicing grande and CT which lead to overcooling of 800 CTW/Barrel ,but we will do a follow up to ensure correct slicing time is followed to avoid underweights.
No under weight bread is accepted to be dispatched to the market and this will be closely monitotered to make sure packed bread is of correct weight.

In the previous audit report dating 13/04/2025 the weights were as follows:

800g BT-46% underweight

400 g Long -29% Underweights.

400g SW-26% underweights.
Current

A weight verification exercise was conducted on 02 June 2025 to assess whether packed bread products ready for dispatch met the required weight specifications. This audit aimed to ensure compliance with product labeling standards, quality assurance protocols, and consumer protection requirements. A variety of bread types were sampled, and the weights were analyzed to identify any instances of underweight or overweight packaging, as well as to evaluate overall consistency in production.

The weight check revealed that while most bread varieties were within acceptable weight limits, significant underweight issues were observed in the 800g CTW category, where 73.5% of samples were below the stated weight, with an average of 775.76g. This represents a critical compliance and quality concern that requires immediate corrective action. Other varieties, including the 600g Barrel and 400g Grande, showed high levels of accuracy, with 96.0% and 82.7% respectively falling within the correct weight range. These findings indicate a need for closer monitoring and calibration of production equipment for the 800g CTW variety, along with a review of quality control procedures to prevent recurrence of such discrepancies.
Operations/Production Department

To determine if the branch was complying with the standard dividing range.

To determine if packed bread was of correct weight as per KEBS standard weights.

attributes.title: Bread damages Analysis
attributes.description:
Analysis of production damages was done for a period of 48 days from 15th  April  2025-1st June  2025 to determine if production damages were within the allowable limit of 0.20%,it was noted that production damages stood at 0.20% of total production which was at par.

Analysis of market damages was done for a period of 48 days from 15th April 2025-1st  June 2025 to determine if market damages were ithin the allowable limit of 0.5%,It was noted that market damages was at 0.33% which was within the allowable limits of 0.50%
attributes.effect: Damages within the allowable threshold implies that branch is producing bread of good quality and proper handling of bread is done by sales team.

value:
Production damages was within range we will put more controls less damages.

We will maintain and put more controls to ensure market damages remain within the allowed range.
To be maintained by making sure bread produced is of good quality.
In the prior audit report production and market damages was at 0.22% and 0.55% respectively.
Current

An analysis of both production and market damages was carried out over a 48-day period from 15 April 2025 to 01 June 2025 to evaluate performance against set Key Performance Indicators (KPIs). The purpose of the review was to determine whether damages occurring during production and in the market remained within acceptable thresholds, and to assess their impact on overall efficiency and product quality. Damage percentages were calculated based on total production and sales values, and findings were compared against defined targets.

The review found that production damages stood at 0.20%, which is exactly at the acceptable limit set by the company. This indicates that while the process is currently within control, any further lapses could push the metric above the allowable threshold, suggesting the need for continued monitoring and minor process improvements.

Market damages were recorded at 0.33%, which is well within the allowable limit of 0.50%. This reflects effective handling and distribution practices, although ongoing vigilance is still required to maintain performance and reduce losses further. Overall, both production and market damages are within set KPIs, showing satisfactory control measures are in place, though opportunities for minor efficiency gains exist.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if production and market damages were within  the allowable limits of 0.2% of total production and 0.5% of total sales respectively.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description: Analysis of packing  efficiency was done for a period of 48 days from 15th April 2025-1st  June 2025 . it was noted that production efficiency was at 93.11 crates per packer which was below the  KPI of 97 crates as illustrated below:
attributes.recommendation: Branch management to ensure allocation of packers is done as per prior shift Loaves produced.
attributes.effect: Packing efficiency was not achieved, 8 excesss packers were hired with a cost implication of Kshs.7296.

value: We will put more controls to ensure slicers attain the set efficiency.
This is noted and follow up to be done to achieve the set target.
In the prior audit report dating 13th April 2025 it was noted that average packing efficiency was at 99.17 crates per packer.
Current

An analysis of packing efficiency was conducted for the period spanning 15 April 2025 to 01 June 2025 to assess workforce utilization and alignment with operational targets. The objective was to determine if the number of packers hired was appropriate relative to output, and whether the actual efficiency met the established Key Performance Indicator (KPI) of 97 crates per packer. This review included adjustments for production damages, free-of-charge items, and specific shift variations to ensure accuracy in evaluating true packing workload and performance.

The audit revealed that actual packing efficiency stood at 93.11 crates per packer, falling short of the target KPI of 97 crates. A total of 201 packers were hired, whereas only 193 would have been necessary had the target efficiency been achieved. This represents an overstaffing of 8 packers, resulting in an estimated cost implication of KES 7,296 over the review period. These findings suggest an opportunity to optimize labor planning and improve workforce efficiency. Aligning actual packing output with established KPIs can help reduce labor costs while maintaining productivity.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if production workers were Optimally utilized by achieving a KPI of 97 crates per packer.

attributes.title: Vehicles fuel analysis
attributes.description:
Analysis of fuel consumption was done for a period of 61 days from   1st April 2025 to 31st May 2025,for the month of April and may fuel consumption was within range ecept for  KCT 952 J -Maili 4 which had consumed excess fuel of 7 litres and 8 litres.

Below is the summary of the finding:
attributes.recommendation: Branch management to ensure allocation of fuel is done as per the standard rates and predetermined distance .
attributes.effect: Minimal variations noted implies that fuel allocation is well controlled.

value: I will check any excess fuel will be recovered.
Controls of fuel issuance will be monitored to be done as per the distance covered .
In the prior audit report dated 13/04/2025 ,it was noted that vehicles fuel consumption was well controlled during the period and Doldol route vehicle had saved 21.85litres for the sample period.
Current

A fuel consumption analysis was carried out over a 61-day period from 01 April 2025 to 31 May 2025 to evaluate fuel usage across company vehicles and ensure alignment with expected consumption rates. The purpose of the review was to identify anomalies, potential inefficiencies, or deviations that may indicate misuse or mechanical issues. Fuel data was compared against standard benchmarks for the respective vehicles.

The analysis showed that fuel consumption was within the acceptable range for all vehicles, except for vehicle KCT 952 J – Maili 4, which recorded excess fuel usage of 7 litres in April and 8 litres in May. While the variance is relatively minor, it warrants follow-up to confirm the cause—such as potential inefficiencies, route deviations, or vehicle condition. Overall, fuel control processes appear effective, but periodic reviews and vehicle-specific monitoring should be continued to sustain efficiency and address any outliers promptly
Operations/Production Department
To determine if fuel allocation was done as per the predetermined distance and standard rates.

attributes.title: Debtors Analysis.
attributes.description: Analysis of debtors as at 01/06/2025 was done to determine if there were any instances of bad debtors,A total of Kshs.552,871 was noted,which most were those of schools and institution with one customer who pays after two days as illustrated below:
attributes.recommendation:
A follow up should be done to ensure pending balances are cleared.

Proactive engagement and consistent monitoring is recommended to maintain healthy cash flow and prevent accumulation of overdue balances
attributes.effect: Insignificant debtors balances implies that the branch debt management controls are working effectively, however Proactive engagement and consistent monitoring are recommended to maintain healthy cash flow and prevent accumulation of overdue balances

value: I will do a follow up with the sales rep.
Sales rep and Rsm are following up with the debts to be cleared.
During the prior audit report,it was observed that schools and other institutions had balances amounting to Ksh 452,568
Current

An analysis of outstanding debtors as at 01 June 2025 was conducted to assess the company’s credit exposure and identify any potential cases of bad debts. The review focused on evaluating the aging and collection status of receivables from various customers, including schools, institutions, and retail outlets. The objective was to establish the collectability of the amounts owed and determine the need for any follow-up actions or provisions.

The review revealed a total outstanding balance of KES 559,736.70, with the majority of debtors comprising schools and institutions, which traditionally settle their accounts through delayed cheque payments. While none of the accounts were deemed irrecoverable at this point, no payments had been received as of the analysis date, and all balances remained fully outstanding. One customer, Veronica Wothaya Mwangi, regularly clears payments within two days of placing an order, indicating lower risk.

Although there are no immediate signs of bad debt, the concentration of receivables in slow-paying institutional clients requires continued follow-up by sales representatives to ensure timely collections and avoid future credit risk. Proactive engagement and consistent monitoring are recommended to maintain healthy cash flow and prevent accumulation of overdue balances
Operations/Production Department
To determine the magnitude of debt balances and to determine if there are any dormant customers that that could pose of default risk.

attributes.title: Production  Efficiency
attributes.description: Production efficiency -Analysis of production efficiency was done for a period of 48 days from 15th April 2025-1st  June 2025 to determine if production workers were achieving their KPI of 4.5 bags per production worker,it was noted that production efficiency stood at 4.75 which is okey.
attributes.effect: Achieved production efficiency implies that production workers are optimally utilized and allocation of production workers is done as per the shift targets.

value: Production efficiency to be maintained.
To be maintained.
In prior audit dated 13/04/2025,it was noted that production efficiency was at 4.79.
Current

As part of the internal audit process, an analysis of production efficiency was conducted over a 48-day period from 15th April 2025 to 1st June 2025. The objective was to assess whether production workers were meeting the established Key Performance Indicator (KPI) of 4.5 bags per worker per day

The analysis revealed that production workers achieved an average efficiency of 4.75 bags per worker per day, exceeding the set KPI. This indicates satisfactory performance in the production area during the review period.
Operations/Production Department
To determine optimal utilization of workers allocated to production area.

attributes.title: Minishop
attributes.description: Mini shop spot check was done on 1st June 2025 to determine if bread loaded was reconciling with the available mpesa amounts, no variations were noted as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: Mini shop controls working effectively to be maintained.

value: Mini shop controls are working effectively.
To be maintained.
Current

A spot check audit was conducted on 1st June 2025 at the Mini Shop to verify whether the bread loaded matched the corresponding M-Pesa cash collections. The objective was to reconcile physical stock movement with sales revenue captured through M-Pesa transactions.

The minor difference noted is fully accounted for by transaction costs, resulting in a net variance of zero. This indicates that proper controls are in place for stock management and sales reconciliation at the Mini Shop, and that staff are accurately recording transactions and handling funds appropriately
Operations/Production Department
To reconcile physical stock movement with sales revenue captured through M-Pesa transactions.

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description: Cash verification was done on02/06/2025 to determine if cash controls was working effectively and to check if cash at hand was in agreement with cashflow balances, Minimal variation of + 2 was noted with IOU which was not yet due the 3 day clearance policy as detailed below:

value: Cash controls working effectively to be maintained.
Cashier encouraged to maintain.

In prior audit dated 13/04/2025,It was noted that the cashier fully accounted for the expected cash balance of Ksh 13,293 as at 14.03.25 after cashing in NSSF contributions from casual which were Ksh 3,827. After rechecking NSSF records, audit noted that there was a variance of Ksh 48. (3,875-3,827)
Current

A cash verification exercise was carried out on 2nd June 2025 to assess the effectiveness of cash controls and ensure that the physical cash at hand aligned with the recorded cash flow balances. The review focused on verifying opening balances, recorded inflows and outflows (IOUs), and reconciling the expected cash balance with the actual cash held

The cash verification exercise shows that cash controls are functioning effectively, with accurate tracking of balances and proper handling of IOUs. The minimal variance of KSh 2 does not indicate any concern and falls within acceptable operational limits. No corrective action is deemed necessary at this time.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if cash at hand is in agreement with cash flow balances.

attributes.title: Generator fuel consumption
attributes.description:
Generator fuel consumption for the month of May was done to determine if fuel allocation was within range.
Generator fuel consumption was at 11.67 litres/hr which was within range as compared with prior months.

value: Fuel consumption controls working effectively.
Genset fueling is well controlled.

In prior audit dated 13/04/2025,it was noted that ,Average consumption for the period was 12.59litres per hour. During the period 34 litres of fuel had been purchased and the generator had run for 2.7hours.
Current

A review of generator fuel consumption for the month of May 2025 was conducted to assess whether fuel usage remained within the expected operational range. The objective was to ensure efficient fuel utilization and detect any potential overconsumption.
The generator's fuel consumption for May 2025 was within the acceptable range, indicating efficient and controlled use of fuel resources. No exceptions were noted.
Operations/Production Department
To determine that generator fuel consumption was well controlled.
